page.title: 13LANDSLIPPING IN VENTNOR.
page.content: Ventnor probably suffers from the worst urban landslipping in Britain. The cause of the slipping is the gault clay that lies between the Upper and Lower Greensand which dips gently towards the sea. The slides are of the multiple rotational type. Blocks of chalk and Upper Greensand, called grabens, break away as the underlying gault clay slides seaward on the Lower Greensand, causing the strata to tilt backwards. Where the graben breaks away fissures or vents are formed. The low cliffs are formed of clay that has slipped from the downs in the past. Although recent landslides have been relatively slight, they have caused damage to roads, houses and utilities. Coastal protection work is taking place to stop the sea aggravating a potentially serious situation.
